['Dharma - Respect for duty, righteousness, and moral law', 'Aarti - Devotion shown to deities through ritualistic lighting of lamps', 'Namaste - Traditional Indian greeting or salutation expressing reverence ', 'Jai Mata Di - A phrase meaning "victory for Mother Goddess," showing respect and devotion to the divine feminine power in Hinduism', "Bhagwan - An honorific term used to refer to gods, with 'Bhag' denoting blessings or divinity", 'Guruji - A title given to a teacher or spiritual guide who inspires deep respect and admiration', 'Swami - Referring to an ascetic in Hindu monastic tradition who embodies wisdom and enlightenment, worthy of reverence ', 'Pundit - An expert on religious scriptures or law who is highly regarded for their knowledge', 'Puja - A ritual worship performed to show devotion towards deities', 'Maharaj - High king or great ruler, a title bestowed upon those of high stature and respected leadership ', 'Yogi/Yogini - One who has attained spiritual wisdom through yoga practice; individuals with such qualities command deep respect', 'Ishvara (or Ishtadevata) - The personal god, an object of devotion that demands utmost reverence and dedication ', 'Veda - Sacred scriptures in Hinduism regarded as authoritative and highly venerated sources of knowledge and guidance', 'Sanatan Dharma: A term referring to the eternal truth or divine law, commanding unconditional respect from its followers', 'Sannyasa: The state of renunciation, a spiritual practice aimed at achieving ultimate liberation; individuals who embody this path are deeply admired ', 'Swami Tulsidas - An esteemed poet-saint known for his devotion to the deity Rama; he is greatly respected in Indian culture', 'Ganga Mata: The personification of the sacred river Ganges and a goddess revered by many Hindus, evoking deep respect through her purifying powers', 'Paramahamsa: A title given to an enlightened or spiritually advanced individual who has transcended societal norms and is held in high esteem', 'Bhakti - Devotional love for the divine; practitioners of this path are regarded with great admiration and respect', "Smarana: The practice of remembrance or veneration, especially towards one' Written by: Daphne Fernandez-Velez and Jannatul Ferdousy Nahar", 'It explores how individuals engage with Facebook as a means to access, create or share political content', 'In the context of elections and political campaigns, it is widely used by citizens as well as politicians in order to garner support or mobilize voters', 'The sample of informants was selected using purposeful sampling; the aim is to obtain rich data from individuals that can shed light on experiences related to digital engagement in politics, especially on social media (Creswell & Plano Clark, 2018)', "The first theme identified is that individuals access news through this platform by following politically-affiliated pages or friends' posts with relevant information (see Figure 1).", 'In order to do this, people follow politicians’ official pages, party-affiliated pages, as well as friends who share relevant posts (see Figure 1)', 'Informants reported being exposed to diverse viewpoints on Facebook, which allows them to broaden their knowledge and understanding of politics', 'The participants did not seem inclined towards posting their own opinions or views, but mostly interacted with existing posts by liking, sharing and commenting; this behavior reflects a common practice where people do not take risks to express themselves (Gonzales-Bayo & Moreno, 2st)', 'This behavior suggests that participants have a routine in which they use this platform to stay updated about politics, but do not invest time into actively engaging or contributing original content', 'For example, one informant recalled how her grandfather had encouraged her to vote during the elections and she posted a message expressing gratitude (see Figure 7)', 'These included difficulties with technical issues such as unstable internet connections and accessibility problems; these limitations sometimes prevented informants from receiving or posting content (see Figure 9)', 'The findings show that most people mainly use Facebook for accessing news and information related to politics, either by following politically-affiliated pages or friends’ posts (see Figure 1)']

['Carotene - A natural pigment found in plants, especially carrots, providing an orange to yellow coloration.', 'Xanthophylls - Yellow-orange pigments found predominantly in the leaves of green plants and algae.', 'Lutein - An essential component for human vision that also imparts a yellow hue to various foods like spinach, corn, and eggs.', 'Chlorophyll - The primary photosynthetic pigment found in plants, which is green but can appear yellowish-brown when aged or degraded.', 'Anthracene - A bipyramidal polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon that appears as black and brown, though certain derivatives may have yellow hues.', 'Saffron - Derived from the stigmas of saffron crocus flowers, it is used for its vibrant red-orange color in culinary applications but also has a yellowish pigment component.', 'Turmeric - A spice obtained from the roots of the Curcuma longa plant; contains curcumin which imparts an intense yellow to orange coloration, with potential shades leaning towards brown when dried or aged.', 'Beta-carotene - An organic pigment that is a precursor for vitamin A and gives carrots their distinctive bright orange color, but can also appear in various browns depending on processing methods.', "Cinnamaldehyde - The compound responsible for the characteristic smell of cinnamon; while it's not typically yellow-brown, when present with other constituents, it could contribute to such a hue in specific products.", 'Curcumin - A bright yellow chemical produced by plants of the family Turpentine (Curcuceae), particularly known for its presence in turmerits and giving them their coloration.', 'Geosmin - An earthy-tasting, yellowish-brown compound produced by certain bacteria found in soil; not a pigment but contributes to the natural flavor of some foods.', 'Cochineal - A red dye obtained from the scale insect Dactylopius coccus, which can have shades ranging from reddish-brown when used in larger quantities or combined with other ingredients.', 'Annatto - Obtained from the seeds of the achiote tree (Bixa orellana), it provides a yellow to orange coloration but may vary towards brown depending on processing and formulation.', "Luteinase - An enzyme that can break down lutein, which is associated with the yellow hue in foods but isn't itself a pigment.", 'Betalains - A class of plant-derived compounds found mainly in beetroot and Swiss chard, giving them their red or yellow color; in aged or processed forms, they can contribute to brownish tones.', 'Chlorophyllin - An extracted form of chlorophyll, used as a food colorant with a green appearance but may exhibit subtle shades towards the brown spectrum when altered.', 'Xanthone derivatives - Chemicals that can be yellow or orange in their original forms; depending on molecular modifications and environmental factors, they could appear brownish.', 'Tannins - Plant compounds known for imparting astringency to foods and beverenas well as contributing to coloration, which might range from green-yellow to brown in certain plants like oak galls.', 'Marigold pigments - Derived from the flowers of Tagetes species; these carotenoids are typically yellow but can turn more brownish upon oxidation or when mixed with other substances.', 'Cinnamon – While primarily known for its aromatic properties, cinnamon bark and oil contain compounds that contribute to the characteristic warm hues of red and orange-brown in their natural state but also can shift towards brownish shades when aged or processed.']

['Combat zone - A specific location designated for military conflict and warfare activities.', 'Fighting field - An area where individuals or groups engage in physical combat or fights.', 'Battleground state - In American politics, this refers to a highly contested state during an election campaign that holds significant importance due to its electoral votes.', 'Firing range - A designated area used for the practice of shooting firearms under controlled conditions.', 'Clash zone - A geographical area where conflicts or confrontations occur between opposing forces.', 'Conflict zone - An area marked by high levels of unrest, violence, and social turmoil due to various disputes or hostilities.', 'Skirmish field - The site of a small-scale battle or conflict involving limited forces.', 'War theater - A broader term referring to regions affected by warfare activities and military operations across different conflicts worldwide.', 'Battlefield museum - An institution dedicated to preserving, displaying, and educating about sites where historic battles occurred.', 'Combat arena - A controlled environment or location for practicing combat skills through simulated or actual fighting scenarios.', 'Riot area - An urban or public space where riots occur, involving large groups of people engaging in violent acts against others.', 'Battleground county - In American politics, this term refers to a politically contested region within a state that holds significant electoral influence during an election campaign.', 'Conflict hotspot - A location where ongoing disputes and clashes occur repeatedly or have high potential for further escalation.', 'War zone city - An urban area heavily impacted by the ongoing conflict, experiencing widespread destruction, displacement of civilians, and challenges to basic services.', 'Combat training ground - A designated location where military personnel practice combat techniques, tactics, and strategies under controlled conditions.', 'Dispute region - An area marked by recurring disagreements or conflicts between different groups, communities, or nations.', 'Battlefront line - The boundary separating opposing forces in a war zone, often the site of intense fighting.', 'Conflict-affected area - A geographical location impacted by violence, instability, and social unrest due to various sources of conflict.', 'Fightscape - An urban or rural setting characterized by frequent clashes between factions or groups with opposing interests.', 'Battleground island - In American politics, this refers to a small-scale battleground state within an electorally significant region, such as the Florida peninsula.']

['Reverse - To turn something around to its opposite direction.', 'Invert - To flip, turn upside down or inside out; reverse in position or order.', 'Overturn - To knock over and change the position of (something heavy) by force.', 'Upset - To tilt or rotate something so that it is no longer upright or normal.', 'Displace - To move from one place to another; shift position, often with an opposite direction in mind.', 'Retrofit - To modify (an existing structure) by adding new technology or features, but can involve reversing the original configuration.', "Reverse engineering - The process of analyzing a product's design to understand its functionality and create a similar one, often going against the initial creation's direction.", 'Counterclockwise - Moving in a circular motion opposite that of the hands of clock; anti-directional around an axis or rotation.', 'Backward - In the opposite direction from usual, forward movement; moving toward the rear.', 'Reverse chronology - A storytelling technique where events are shown starting with their end and then progressing to the beginning in reverse order.', 'Antithesis - The direct opposite of a concept or idea.', 'Antecedent - In linguistics, it refers to a word that an anaphoric expression (like pronoun) refers back to; however, in terms of directionality, "antecedent" doesn\'t quite fit the pattern but can imply something coming before.', 'Posterior - The rear part of something, especially when referring to parts of the body', 'Opposite - Ancillary or directly contrary in nature; does not imply direction but fits the theme of being the other way round conceptually.', 'Reverse biasing - Applying an opposite electrical potential to a transistor, affecting its operation.', 'Negation - The denial or contradiction of something, metaphorically "turning it around."', 'Countervail - To counteract the effect; while not directional in nature, implies opposing an existing force or direction.', 'Converse - In logic, to form a statement by reversing its terms (though typically used for logical operations).', "Inverted - Turned upside down or inside out; though commonly denoting physical orientation, can refer to the metaphorical 'other way around' in contexts like light polarization."]
